Award.AwardTitle: Support for Participation in Logic and Computational Complexity: Workshop in Honor of Neil Immerman

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The grant provides travel support for graduate students to attend the 2014 Logic and Computational Complexity Workshop that will take place in Vienna, Austria, on July 12-13, 2014, which is taking place during the Vienna Summer of Logic event, which encompasses the Federated Logic Conferences (FLoC'2014). Funding for student travel has significant broader impacts because of the opportunity it gives the students to become part of their research community, discuss their research with others, listen to and meet with leaders in the field. This workshop is international and provides an international dimension, because students will have experiences relevant to becoming part of a global workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided support for the participation of graduate students from US universities in the 2014 Logic and Computational Complexity Workshop (LCC) that took place in Vienna, Austria, on July 12-13, 2014, as well as participation in the 2015 IEEE/ACM Automated Software Engineering Conference (ASE) that took place  in Lincoln, Nebraska, on November 9-13, 2015.

Logic and Computational Complexity (LCC) is a workshop series aimed at the foundational interconnections between logic and computational complexity, as present, for example, in implicit computational complexity (descriptive and type-theoretic methods); deductive formalisms as they relate to complexity (e.g., ramification, weak comprehension, bounded arithmetic, linear logic and resource logics); complexity aspects of finite model theory and databases; complexity-mindful program derivation and verification; computational complexity at higher type; and proof complexity. In 2014, the workshop was dedicated to celebrating the accomplishments of Prof. Neil Immerman who has been a leading figure in the development of descriptive complexity theory, which is one of the core topics of LCC. LCC 2014 is the 17th in a series of workshops that started in 1994.  The 2014 workshop was part of the Vienna Summer of Logic, which attracted approximately 2000 researchers and provided unparalleled exposure to contemporary logic-related research and networking opportunities.

At LCC, the grant provided partial support for several graduate student, and thus exposed them to cutting-edge research in the area of logic and complexity. The concentration of researchers in this subject in one place is rare (especially so for those coming from the US). As logic is gaining renewed interest in many areas of CS beyond theory, support for attending the workshop allowed young researchers in these fields who are interested in logic to gain both a valuable historical perspective as well as to learn about current research directions on an aspect of logic particularly relevant to CS.

ASE is the premier research conference for automated software engineering. In 2015, ASE brought together over 250 researchers and practitioners to discuss foundations, techniques and tools for automating the analysis, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance of large software systems. 

 At ASE, graduate students had the opportunity to engage with experts while learning about the state-of-the-art in automated software engineering research. In addition to the presentation of 55 technical research papers, the program included 5 experience papers, and 16 new ideas papers. ASE also featured a tool demo track, and included two panels. There were five workshops and six tutorials as well as a Doctoral Symposium and two social events. The Doctoral Symposium was a full day symposium that provided students with useful guidance and feedback on their dissertation research and facilitated networking within the scientific community by interacting with established researchers and with their peers at a similar stage in their careers.  Student feedback indicated that their participation in these activities played an important role in their training and academic career development.
